Comments_List: increased familiarity with Tacitean prose style, introduction to key interpretive issues in study of both history and classical historiography
My knowledge of Latin improved, and my familiarity with Tacitus increased.

This course greatly contributed to my knowledge of Latin historiography, and provided keen insight into Tacitus' historical project. It improved my reading of Latin prose, increasing my vocabulary and strengthening my ability to work through a text. It was conceptually stimulating and intellectually challenging, leaving me with a desire to learn more about the topic and read more Tacitus.
Prof. Kraus organized the course well and was flexible in tailoring the course to the different backgrounds and needs of students.
This was a great course.  There was a good balance of Latin translation, discussion of the text, and discussion of secondary literature.

No real weaknesses of the course. It was very challenging and sometimes it was stressful to have completed say two-thirds of the assignment and then come to class and have us focus on the one-third I hadn't done, but such is life. The course provides a very thorough consideration of the portions of the Histories that we read.

Absolutely! I would say this course is a must-take for all graduate students in Classics, as well as anyone (undergraduate or graduate) who reads Latin and is interested in the problems involved in "writing history."
Yes.  This was an enjoyable and useful course.
I would definitely recommend this course to anyone with an interest in Latin historiography. It was an excellent experience and I gained a lot from it despite it being very challenging.
